Question_1.Context: The study focused on analyzing the behavior of hoop stress and stress concentration factors in thick-walled cylinders with radial cross bores under internal pressure. The aim was to determine the impact of cross bore size and thickness ratio on stress levels.
Question_1.Question: What was the aim of the study mentioned in the text?
Question_1.A: To determine the behavior of the hoop stress in thin-walled cylinders.
Question_1.B: To analyze the impact of temperature on stress concentration factors.
Question_1.C: To establish the optimal Stress Concentration Factors (SCF) in thick-walled cylinders with radial cross bores.
Question_1.D: To investigate the effect of external pressure on stress distribution in cylinders.
Question_1.Source: The aim of this study was to determine the behaviour of the hoop stress as well as to establish the optimal Stress Concentration Factors (SCF).

Question_2.Context: The study involved cylinders with thickness ratios ranging from 3.0 down to 1.4 and cross bore size ratios ranging from 0.1 to 1.0.
Question_2.Question: What were the ranges of thickness ratios and cross bore size ratios studied in the experiment?
Question_2.A: Thickness ratios from 2.0 to 3.5 and cross bore size ratios from 0.5 to 1.5.
Question_2.B: Thickness ratios from 1.0 to 2.5 and cross bore size ratios from 0.1 to 0.5.
Question_2.C: Thickness ratios from 3.0 to 1.4 and cross bore size ratios from 0.1 to 1.0.
Question_2.D: Thickness ratios from 2.5 to 4.0 and cross bore size ratios from 0.3 to 0.8.
Question_2.Source: Cylinders of thickness ratios of 3.0 down to 1.4 with cross bore size ratios (cross bore to main bore ratio) ranging from 0.1 to 1.0 were studied.

Question_3.Context: The study found that the maximum hoop stress increased with the increase in the cross bore size.
Question_3.Question: How did the maximum hoop stress behave in relation to the cross bore size?
Question_3.A: Decreased with increasing cross bore size.
Question_3.B: Remained constant regardless of the cross bore size.
Question_3.C: Increased with increasing cross bore size.
Question_3.D: Was not affected by the cross bore size.
Question_3.Source: The maximum hoop stress was found to increase with the increase in the cross bore size.

Question_4.Context: The study mentioned that the lowest Stress Concentration Factor (SCF) occurred with a cross bore size ratio of 0.1 at a specific thickness ratio.
Question_4.Question: At what thickness ratio did the lowest SCF occur with a cross bore size ratio of 0.1?
Question_4.Source: Moreover, the lowest SCF occurred in the smallest cross bore size ratio of 0.1 at a thickness ratio of 2.25 with a SCF magnitude of 2.836.

Question_5.Context: The study highlighted that the SCF magnitude indicated a reduction of pressure-carrying capacity of 64.7% in comparison to a similar plain cylinder without a cross bore.
Question_5.Question: By how much percentage was the pressure-carrying capacity reduced with the optimal cross bore size?
Question_5.Source: This SCF magnitude indicated a reduction of pressure-carrying capacity of 64.7% in comparison to a similar plain cylinder without a cross bore.

Question_6.Context: The study observed that the SCF increased with the increase in the cross bore size.
Question_6.Question: How did the Stress Concentration Factor (SCF) behave in relation to the cross bore size?
Question_6.A: Decreased with increasing cross bore size.
Question_6.B: Remained constant regardless of the cross bore size.
Question_6.C: Increased with increasing cross bore size.
Question_6.D: Was not affected by the cross bore size.
Question_6.Source: It was observed that the magnitude of SCF increased with increase in the cross bore size.

Question_7.Context: The study mentioned that the optimal SCF was found at the smallest cross bore size ratio of 0.1.
Question_7.Question: Where was the optimal SCF found in relation to the cross bore size?
Question_7.A: At the largest cross bore size ratio of 1.0.
Question_7.B: At the smallest cross bore size ratio of 0.1.
Question_7.C: At a cross bore size ratio of 0.5.
Question_7.D: At a cross bore size ratio of 0.7.
Question_7.Source: Amongst the five cross bore sizes studied, the smallest cross bore size ratio of 0.1 gave the lowest magnitude of SCF of 2.836 at K = 2.25.

Question_8.Context: The study concluded that the rise in hoop stress due to the size of the cross bore reduced with an increase in the thickness ratio.
Question_8.Question: How did the rise in hoop stress behave in relation to the thickness ratio?
Question_8.C: Remained constant regardless of the thickness ratio.
Question_8.D: Was not affected by the thickness ratio.
Question_8.Source: The rise in hoop stress due to the size of the cross bore reduces with increase in thickness ratio.

Question_9.Context: The study found that the location of the maximum hoop stress generally occurred along the radial cross bore.
Question_9.Question: Where did the location of the maximum hoop stress generally occur?
Question_9.B: At the center of the cylinder.
Question_9.D: At the end of the cylinder.
Question_9.Source: The location of the maximum hoop stress on the cylinder generally occurred along the radial cross bore.

Question_10.Context: The study highlighted that the SCF was lowest at the smallest cross bore size ratio of 0.1 and highest at the largest cross bore size of 1.0.
Question_10.Question: Where was the highest SCF reported in relation to the cross bore size?
Question_10.A: At the smallest cross bore size ratio of 0.1.
Question_10.B: At a cross bore size ratio of 0.5.
Question_10.C: At a cross bore size ratio of 0.7.
Question_10.D: At the largest cross bore size ratio of 1.0.
Question_10.Source: In contrast, the highest SCF in the cylinder was reported in the largest cross bore size of 1.0.
